stem: A client with resolving diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is being transitioned from an intravenous (IV) insulin infusion to subcutaneous (SQ) insulin glargine and lispro. Based on the documentation in the Serial DKA & Medication Administration Log, which action by the nurse is the most critical for preventing a recurrence of ketoacidosis?

options.text: Continue the IV insulin infusion for 1–2 hours after the SQ insulin is administered.
Stop the IV insulin infusion exactly at 1000 when the glargine is given.
Discontinue the IV insulin 30 minutes before giving the SQ insulin.
Stop the IV infusion only once the next blood glucose is > 250 mg/dL.

rationale.correct: The most critical action is to **overlap the IV and SQ insulin (a1)**. Subcutaneous insulin (especially basal insulin like glargine) takes time to be absorbed and reach a therapeutic level in the blood. Because IV insulin has a very short half-life (minutes), stopping it at the same time as the SQ dose is given creates an 'insulin gap,' which can trigger a rapid return to ketosis. Standard practice is to continue the IV drip for 1–2 hours after the first SQ dose.
clinicalPearls: The 'Overlap' rule: SQ insulin first, wait 2 hours, then IV insulin off.
Rebound ketosis is a common reason for ICU readmission in DKA patients.
Glargine (Lantus) has no peak, making the overlap even more important for steady-state coverage.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that giving IV and SQ insulin at the same time will cause lethal hypoglycemia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While hypoglycemia is a risk, the greater risk in a resolving DKA patient is the recurrence of the acidosis due to lack of basal insulin. The overlap is a safety mandate in most hospital protocols.

mnemonic.title: Double the Dose
mnemonic.expansion: SQ insulin in, IV insulin drip stays. Wait 2 hours, clear the haze (Stop the drip).

exhibits.content:
